title: Former TPG Executive William McGlashan Jr. Sentenced to Three Months in College Admissions Case
sub_head: Mr. McGlashan admitted to participating in test-cheating scheme
body:
Former private-equity star William McGlashan Jr. was sentenced Wednesday to three months in prison for paying a college counselor to fudge his son’s college entrance exam score and boost the teen’s chance of admission.
Mr. McGlashan founded TPG’s Growth Fund and, along with Irish rock star Bono and former eBay Inc. President Jeff Skoll, co-founded the social-impact Rise Fund.
He admitted earlier this year to paying $50,000 to college counselor William “Rick” Singer so a proctor could fix his son’s wrong answers on the ACT. Mr. McGlashan arranged to have his son take the test at a school in West Hollywood, Calif., in December 2017, where a proctor could improve his score after the teen completed the exam. Mr. McGlashan said his son didn’t know about the scheme.
Wednesday’s sentencing, done remotely in federal court in Boston, is the latest activity in the far-reaching college admissions cheating scandal that prosecutors unveiled in March 2019 and dubbed Operation Varsity Blues. Twenty-five other parents have been sentenced in the case, their punishments ranging from probation to nine months in prison. In total, 57 people were charged, including coaches, a university athletics administrator, a test proctor and test site administrators.
Parents who pleaded not guilty are scheduled to stand trial in September. Coaches and a University of Southern California administrator are slated for trial in November.
